review_title: Started off good then got worse

review_title: Things are a mess at the organization level
pros: Ideation is glorified, and benefits are great.
cons:
Limited bandwidth for execution. Leadership is generally aloof to mid- and entry-level employees. You spend a great deal of your time in meetings not knowing why you’re in them. They’re generally redundant discussions, and most times, you won’t get an agenda prior to joining. I was often volunteered for projects without warning and expected to speak on something I wasn’t working on. I also never received a performance review, and despite asking for one, was often given a task list out of context instead. I wouldn’t expect too much professional development or mentorship here. 

Additionally, you’ll be asked for input, but the irony is that your superiors have already made the decision about what ideas and tasks will and won’t be executed. The request for input from you is purely performative, as are many of the campaigns around cultural inclusion. Leadership is not interested in real, systemic change, only PR materials.

Working here takes a toll on your mental health. I had a period after my 90 days when I was dealing with grief, so I opted out of certain meetings. When I told my supervisor about it, she initially gave me a response of indifference, which I was put off by, but chose to ignore it. HR nevertheless gave me approval to continue opting out when necessary.

Further, my first task when I came onboard was to hire an associate-level employee, as our former one had parted a month after I arrived. A full *8 months* later, we have not hired one and only recently did I receive support from the recruiting department. As a result, most of my tasks have been entry-level and my skills have been seriously set back. It’s very clear that executives have more of an interest in expanding their own professional network than they do in hiring support for their mid- and entry-level staff, as they have been more keen on hiring leadership roles than anyone else. For a nonprofit, they are not considerate, thoughtful, or encouraging.

Finally, if you ask for support, it’ll often be deflected as a problem stemming from you rather than external factors. It’s condescending, but they get away with it.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Pros
Higher pay than most mental health orgs
Good fringe benefits (some are better than others)
Lots of smart people who really believe in the mission however, these numbers are few and far between. See below.
cons:
Cons
Where do I begin?
If you enjoy backstabbing, lying, pettiness, and have a thirst for getting ahead at any cost you will enjoy working at Crisis Text Line. All jokes aside, the management and leadership staff at Crisis Text Line, bar a few, are some of the worst people to have as much power as they do.

It is strange to work for an organization with such a strong dedication to mental health and supporting those in crisis when at the same time, the people in charge consistently and ruthlessly display none of the same qualities required to lead staff. For example, there is a Director that is also a full therapist who treats CTL as their second job. 
Decisions that affect the mental well-being, health, family and wealth of those employees are made behind closed doors with complete disregard for how it will affect others.

Be prepared for public floggings during meetings with horrendous negativity and shaming on display for all. Meetings became so bad at one point we were told not to record their contents so as to protect the company's liability. If that isn’t a major flag, I don’t know what else is. 

Alongside these issues, we have people who have no clinical mental health experience who are making decisions that literally impact the health and safety of the very people texting for help. 

There are plenty of policies, procedures and decisions made that fly in the face of laws, which I’m sure, given enough investigations, would uncover very bad outcomes for those involved. 

Much is being made about a transformation towards equity and inclusion which means the organization is doing a 180 and embracing so much “wokeness” so if that’s your bag just know that all the effort in the company is focused on this and not actually improving the core mission of the organization.

job_title: Volunteer Crisis Counselor in New York, NY
pros:
- Initial training was good from an online perspective 
- Process was quick and easy to get started
cons:
Where do I start? 
- From day 1 I was basically having "conversations" with limited to no support which was not how it was sold to me during training
- Supervisors appear to do nothing on "the platform" and I have never once been reached out to personally by a "supervisor" when I've started a shift
- The policies, procedures and approaches are unclear and the safety of those texting in is dubious at best. To me at night it looks like people are waiting HOURS for someone to help them. WHILE IN CRISIS! One person I texted with had waited, no joke, 5 hours to speak to someone. 
- From what I've been able to gather most of the "staff" do not have any professional experience in crisis intervention, psychology, mental health or safety. I've asked around and most don't even have a Masters degree and it was unclear if some had a Bachelors degree
- One "supervisor" admitted in chat that they had fallen asleep as I volunteer at night due to my work schedule which they laughed about
- I get random emails from someone that is supposed to help with engagement but their emails but are very unclear what on earth they are going on about and why they are emailing everyone
- After volunteering for more than 10+ months I've NEVER had or been asked to refresh or update my learning/training so I assume that is an organization wide problem?
- Last year their CEO was fired and a huge amount of negativity surrounded the company to do with racism etc.

review_title: Great cause - but it's a tech company first and foremost
pros:
- I loved my work and my job! It's still a small company so you get to work with people in all departments.
- There are tons of amazing, brilliant people that you get to learn from every day.
- Even when you have a bad day, you get to go home knowing that in some small way you've made a huge impact on someone else's life. 
- The company is open to pivoting in new directions if one way doesn't seem to be working. This can also be a negative as sometimes the company moves too quickly away from something before seeing it through.
- Relaxed work environment. The office environment is very open and laid back. There are also lots of chances to work remotely.
cons:
- The opportunities for growth are based on luck. It's all about what project you get and when. It's great to see people who deserve promotions get them, but often it's about right place, right time and not about skill or effort.
- This is a company with a focus on mental heath, yet the mental heath of staff is often not taken into account at all.  Crisis Text Line may seem like a mental health company, but they act more like a  tech startup with their employees.

review_title: Mix Messages of Quantity or Quality
pros:
- Great training
- Rewarding work to those in need
- Tech team does a lot of great work to make site more usable for counselors
cons:
My first three months here were great, but during the last three, I'm starting to become concerned over the mixed messages towards counselors during times of high volume. When I was first trained, there were very specific rules re: the quality of our conversations for a variety of issues. I felt very secure in what I needed to do in order to give the best care to our texters. 

Now that volume has picked up, sometimes due to the company's own initiative, there is a push to handle as much quantity as possible, with limited time for convos not categorized as a "crisis," including asking right away if they are actually in a crisis....and limiting the time with them to 30 minutes, or immediately turning them away to a referral site.

I'm afraid a lot of counselors are way too obsessed with the volume they are taking in to make numbers or earn rewards instead of focusing on why we are there in the first place...to help others. Also...there is a weird idolatry of leaders in the company.

Staff seems very stretched thin and are unable to always provide support to texters...can feel very isolating during shifts.

pros: It has potential to be a great opportunity to help others.
cons: I've been taking conversations with texters for almost a full year and have not received ANY feedback even ONCE. Sure, I completed the training process and I luckily also have experience working in the mental health field, but I am extremely concerned that I have never been given positive OR negative feedback after volunteering 4 hours a week for nearly a year. Moreover, I have been transferred conversations from other crisis counselors that have been HORRIBLE (improper spelling and grammar, insensitive messages, etc.). To think that other counselors might not be getting feedback seriously worries me! I want to help people, but there really isn't any accountability here and a high turnover rate of volunteers. Also, the supervisors on the platform seem very overwhelmed. I ask occasional questions for clarity because I want to do the best possible job helping each texter, but some supervisors seem annoyed answering even one question per shift. Finally, we are encouraged to take as many conversations as possible, but this is NOT HELPFUL for the texters. I'd rather have one or two conversations at a time where I can really focus on the texters and provide real, attentive help. It seems like Crisis Text Line prefers quantity over quality, which is sad.

cons: It really takes a lot out of you to work for an organization which specializes in crisis intervention. At points you can feel completely worn out and as though the end result is not enough. At points working 12 hours a week can feel like another job. I felt that at points I was missing out on social interaction outside of the computer screen. Another difficult part of working for the organization is that working with the texters for so long can leave you emotionally damaged in a way, as you cannot share what is going in the conversations and how they made you feel with anyone outside the platform. review_title: "Volunteer Crisis Counselor- This experience has been an astonishingly worthwhile one"
pros: Where do I start? There's soooo many pros of being a volunteer crisis counselor with this organization, Crisis Text Line.  To keep it short and not to be overly chatty, you receive amazing training, loads of consistent support from your coach and your warm and ever alert supervisors, and you get to impact the lives of people in need of empathy and support during moments they are in crisis.  It has enriched my life in so many unexpected ways and now I have come to see empathy as a superpower. Crisis Text Line as an organizations goes out of its way to support you in being there for texters in the ways they deserve (and desire).  I've volunteered a lot and this is a terrific way to be a part of something that adds to our world's community. :)
cons: The only con of being a volunteer crisis counselor- and I'm speaking for myself- is probably an obvious one (or maybe not)- hoping your impact goes far enough when dealing with and talking to each and every texter.  Don't worry. It does.

review_title: mixed bag at the crisis text line
pros: a chance to give back
cons: Heartbreaking trauma experiences we learn about from texters

review_title: Meaningful work for volunteers, horrific for employees
pros: Meaningful work. Great mission. Potential for a lot of impact in mental health work. Inspiring to volunteer and to work with crisis counselor trainess. Most of entry level and mid level employees are wonderful. Pay is decent.
cons:
Laughably terribly managed organization. CEO needs to seriously evaluate values, but lacks any ability for empathy or introspection so I'm not holding my breath. Blatant discrimination and racism. No HR (and CEO declares the company doesn't need one - it does). Told over and over your degree has no value at the org. Nearly all employees are incredibly disgruntled and unhappy. People leave the organization in tears. Job responsibilities constantly change with no warning, especially in training team. Incredibly long hours. Feedback to management is met with derision, ignored completely, or dismissed outright.

More than employee unhappiness, the org has struck several ill advised deals with funders. You are forced to accept more and more trainees and graduate them in massive numbers even though you know many aren't ready to actually help people in crisis. Still, the org needs to meet metrics for money so you are pressured to graduate them. From this pressure, data is also deliberately manipulated to meet metrics. 

Bottom line - working at Crisis Text Line is just an ethical and demoralizing mess.
