review_title: For the love of all things holy, do not work here or use this service!
pros: I met some lovely people who I've remained friends with.
cons:
The company is rotten, through and through. Positive reviews are either volunteers who don't know the inner workings of the company, or planted by management. 

Truly the worst company culture I have ever been a part of,  AND I WORKED FROM HOME! It permeates your entire life because you're expected to live, breath, and eat CTL. 

Fear is the only tool utilized by Empress Lublin. If you want some insight into the way the company is run, listen to that podcast 'The Drop Out' about Elizabeth Holmes. It is stunningly similar.  

No standards for ethics or required certifications for supervisors. I can truly say that I would never recommend this service to anyone in crisis.  I have seen how poorly trained and supervised some of the crisis counselors are. Some are amazing, but you have no idea what you're going to get when you text in. Could be someone who helps you, could just as easily be someone who makes things worse.

Do yourself a favor and look elsewhere if you find yourself in need.

pros:
I give full credit to Nancy Lublin's leadership and high tech vision of continuous learning, for keeping this big tribe of volunteers sharp and on track.  In my Crisis Counselor role, I benefit from my shift supervisors' personal coaching, cheers to them, but also the continuously refined training materials:  I soak up the YouTube "how to" videos, weekly newsletters  and the often surprising metrics the algorithms tease out 

But most surprising has been how positively the CTL experience has impacted my everyday life and made me a more insightful friend and colleague.  Working for Crisis Text Line is a win-win.
cons:
The thought of the responsibility can be frightening, at first.  It was for me, but now I’m rolling and confident with 500 texted conversations behind me.  

Even though I am only one of almost 4000 who volunteer as a Crisis Counselor every month, I feel supported and guided by ongoing coaching and training.  You will, too.  Join us. There is a lot of pain in America.

review_title: Volunteer.  Very poor and unprofessional training approach.
pros: I am a psychologist with 30 years in the mental health field working with adolescents and young adults. I was excited about volunteering with CTL and had recommended CTL to many as a resource when I did formal trainings and presentations on suicide prevention. I dropped out of the training after a month and expressed my concern about the highly rigid, scripted responses and procedures that were not ethical nor did I feel met professional standards for mental health emergency care.  The response I received from a 'trainer' was,  'bummer!'
cons: You lost a person who had the desire, knowledge and experience to give back. I'm sure I am not the only one. I do not recommend CTL any longer.

job_title: Crisis Counselor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I am a volunteer crisis counselor at the Crisis Text Line and have been for almost a year now. Not only is the work invaluable to so many people, but the organization pays it forward to its volunteers with tons of support, training and positive reinforcement. This goes for all levels of management - CTL's CEO Nancy Lublin is in regular contact, cheering on her team and making sure we have the tools to do what we're doing... which is helping save lives. It's a tribute to her vision that millions of people have been helped so far, and millions more are benefiting from the incredible insights this data-driven company is sharing on how to better respond to people in crisis.
cons: The subject matter is heavy - obviously - so it's not for everyone. But I do feel well-trained and confident because of it, so that's a pro to the con =)

pros: It's a nice place to work as far as for volunteering.
cons: My only gripe would be that they only hire people who lives in certain location hubs or you have to transfer to that location. What I don't understand is why transfer to a location when everything is mostly online.

pros:
This is my experience as a VOLUNTEER

-Flexible hours at home
-Rewarding work
- Lots of recognition/rewards for volunteers
-fun benefits/perks/events
- Had positive experiences with supervisors on the platform (I don't typically reach out anyways and on slow shifts most reach out and say hi or ask about your day)
-The training and nature of the work has positively impacted how I go about all of my relationships.
-Youth Advisory Council adding more to what you can do as a volunteer
-A lot of negative, disturbing reviews are from staff/higher ups/CEO that you SHOULD read, even if you're only a volunteer Crisis Counselor. However, please don't let this turn you away completely from volunteering- it is truly an amazing, much needed line of work. On my end, I haven't had negative/any interaction with those awful higher ups, so overall it's been a really positive, joyful, fulfilling volunteer opportunity that I'm grateful to be apart of. Definitely reconsidering my blind idolization and worship of the org after reading these reviews.  Luckily that negative culture doesn't really seem to trickle down to the volunteer level.
cons:
-I agree with others posted that more feedback would be great. Apparently there is an approval rating for each Crisis Counselor so I think allowing CCs to see this would be amazing for personal growth. Each CC has a Coach (doesn't seem like they have many responsibilities) so having them review this with CCs would be great.
- I agree from other posts that a lot of insensitive statements are pushed. I do encourage most CCs to ignore suggested convo amounts and take whatever you feel comfortable with- don't sweat the noise and go with your gut, not what a disconnected newsletter suggests you say.   
- Lack of response from staff regarding platform suggestions

pros: The mission of the organization is wonderful and much needed. The staff has very smart, committed people. The volunteers are sweet.
cons: Ironically, I was warned about the CEO from an employee of the last organization she led (Do Something). Given the general positive media she has received and thinking that I've handled working with "interesting" personalities I decided to give it a shot. Unfortunately, I've had to find out for myself what true organizational dysfunction looks like, along with downright abusive management with tons of little racial microagressions that look like they belong from a scene out of an over the top corporate training video. As with the last organization, she took a good idea and turned it into a platform for personal glorification.

pros: Crisis Text Line is a rare org that saves lives like a nonprofit and builds things like a tech startup. The environment is extremely collaborative and not just as a platitude: members of the company at all levels get to share their ideas and review others and everyone on the team is ready to pitch in and help. It would be tough to find a more caring crew. And at the same time, people are analytical, motivated, skilled and thoughtful. The exec team is extremely mindful of the heavy nature of this space and goes above and beyond to  mitigate the challenge of this work with fun activities. Self care is a big thing here- it's actually a really fun place to work. Lastly, there are always interesting and inspirational people coming through the office, with lots of opportunities for employees to advance themselves.
cons: It's work hard play hard- if you're not into that than this isn't for you.

pros: Everyone is nice for the most part.
cons: I've been here almost two years and I've seen a lot of changes. Most not good. The new supervisors don't appear to have any actual qualifications.  Supervisors have shrugged off imminent risk conversations saying that teenagers are dramatic. Supers have also suggested we ask texters if they want to report verbal abuse but when a texter is being physically abused they say we can't report it because they don't have bruises. We're encouraged to take as many convos as possible and close out anyone not imminent risk at 15 minutes. Not only is this overwhelming but texters hate us for it. They don't feel supported at all. When a post goes viral we're all expected to jump on and help out. Meanwhile we don't have the counselors to back this queue up. Not only am I getting texts at night asking for help but they'll text me and ask if I can jump on during the week. I used to LOVE working here but ever since the new supervisors came in and the old ones left, I hate it. They're never helpful and I'm genuinely concerned someone will take their life because of the neglect of supers. I'm here for the texters but I'm afraid I'll be involved in the passing of a texter because my super was negligent. Nancy, the CEO, shared a post about how she helped save someone from a sex ring. The post went viral. What about texter confidentiality? How did you get permission for that? WHY WOULD YOU ASK A VICTIM IF YOU CAN PUBLICLY SHARE THAT?! Using someone elses story to make her organization look good so she gets more donations. I want to leave CTL but I love the work I do here and I can't abandon my texters. We genuinely care about other people. If you have a bad experience with us it's likely because we're forced into a certain script. I'm so sorry for any possible damage I may have caused anyone due to the neglect of the staff. There is not HR department and Nancy says they don't need one. Ugh.

review_title: Some amazing people, pretty bad management
pros:
-Entry level and mid level employees are kind, fun, and motivated.
-Good networking opportunities - if you're on the exec team's good side.
-It's a good job if you're working from home.
-Amazing an inspirational cause.
cons:
-People get fired for not getting along with or disagreeing with the exec team and then are bashed publicly after they leave.
-The exec team cannot handle constructive criticism. At all.
-No HR.
-A lot of major decisions are made impulsively.
-This job is more than full time. You are expected to go WAY above and beyond your job description.
-There is a tense office environment, as everyone is walking on eggshells around the exec team.

pros: Great mission and using technology to make solutions smarter. Look out for the difference in ratings here between volunteer crisis counselors and actual employees. Different experiences.
cons: The CEO is unable to see the impact she has when she meddles with the work that should belong to her leaders and managers. She blames and points fingers not realizing it all points back to her. She surrounds herself with weak skill sets from her people so she can manipulate them and remain the only  decision maker.  Her co founder is incapable of standing up to her, HR is a joke, and others rationalize the bad behavior because they’ve been manipulated by supposed career opportunities she doles out without giving them actual authority.

pros: Can't think of anything worth the mental abuse and racism of the CEO and complicity of the management team
cons:
Not a place to work if you value your confidence, happiness or mental health.

I encourage you to read the reviews here, that are buried among fake reviews written by the COO, who has been directly told to do so by the CEO. 

The employees have tried to speak up and call attention to the abuse that happens on a daily basis - reached out to journalists, the board, etc. but the CEO has repeatedly done everything in her power to have us silenced. 

If you're considering applying for a job here - do NOT. Also, go read old reviews from her previous organization. This is not a recent issue. This "leader" has just never been checked.

pros:
-If you are willing to give feedback and communicate the issues at hand, the org is willing to accommodate to provide a positive experience.
- The CEO works her butt off to make sure we are funded and gaining partnerships to make this service possible to those who truly need all while maintaining a family. 
-The benefits are amazing and they really take into account the struggles of remote employees. 
-The start-up culture and constant change is so exciting and innovative; it's so fulfilling to dream up products and bring them to life.
-AMAZING benefits and opportunities to travel.
cons: -it's hard to unplug being remote; this is not an org problem but a personal one that takes practice and a conscious effort; self-care is so important.

review_title: Impactful work with a great group of people
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
-Extremely passionate, kind and talented people
-Clear organizational wide goals
-Work that saves lives everyday (you can't beat that for impact!)
-Multitude of opportunities for leadership
-Very flat - Serious responsibility across all positions
-Transparent -  Explanations of 'why' are always given with every decision. Plus, open data!
cons:
-Fast pace - This drives me, it's not for everyone
- Heavy topics - We are, after all, a crisis line. Again many find this motivating to roll up your sleeves and dig in, some don't
- Always on - Our service is 24/7 so it's important to set personal boundaries and practice self care. This can be a challenge for some.

pros: I met some very passionate and competent people during my time there.
cons:
Crisis Text Line is an awful place to work. As a place that supposedly prides itself on empathy, kindness and self care they do not extend that to their own employees. The CEO has some major biases when it comes to how she treats the different teams and whom she deems deserving of elevating without the company. There’s plenty covert racism, micro aggressions and the use of black and brown employees for face value to appear diverse. The culture of this company is to call everything “awesome” and calling people “rockstars” which really leans to a particular kind of culture and often doesn’t feel inclusive. 

Crisis text line as a whole and upper management teams are mainly comprised of white people and therefore they place many non-people of color in management and lead positions because of course you promote people that look like you and you believe you have more in common with. Just imagine your white counterparts with little experience at CTL or in the mental health field overall becoming your manager after 6 months to a year of being with the company. How can this person lead me or help me develop skills that will help me get to the nonexistent next level at Crisis Text Line when they never had to do any of those things themselves? The lack of clarity regarding the steps to being up for promotion and the clear favoritism creates a culture of backstabbing among team members because of course everyone wants to get ahead. 

The loudest person in the room or the person that can weaponize their tears the best gets the promotion regardless of how well they function in their position. The quarterly review process is a joke because it’s arbitrary and often my manager was unable elaborate when assessment questions were unclear. HR is 1 person and doesn’t give much insight into what her purpose actually is because it wasn’t define the positions and provide a clear path to moving up the corporate ladder. Titles were provided without any steps to get to said title and when I asked my manager she was unable to provide any info due to the lack of follow through by HR and upper management to complete the process. 

Self care is nonexistent because the workload and the scheduling process is volatile.  You never know when things will change and how it will impact your life outside of Crisis Text Line i.e school, family, hobbies, vacations, etc. I would literally get sick to my stomach on the day before my work week started because the job was so toxic and I often felt trapped. I knew I was never going to get a promotion despite being told how great I was at my job because I’m not white woman or a white man that could get in good with the white women. 

Here’s an example of what a black or brown person has to bring to the table vs their white counterpart: A white woman with a 4yr education degree was COO and ultimately quit; the black woman that replaced her was a literal doctor with an extensive background in trauma. When that doctor exited the company due to all of the CEOs toxic behaviors and alienation of her black and brown employees she was replaced by a white woman that might have been with the agency for 1yrs and had multiple complaints against her as a team leader. She had no track record of being a director of anything trauma or crisis intervention related. 

This job will leave you feeling like you are wasting your time. Being a Supervisor at Crisis Text Line is not a mental health position and you will not be developing any clinical skills here so don’t bother.  There’s no clinical supervision provided so please know that if your licensure requires this you will have to seek it elsewhere. Please read other reviews that are not by crisis counselors/volunteers because they are not actual Crisis Text Line employees and therefore can only review the actual crisis counseling piece to Crisis Text Line.

pros: Opportunity to help others in their time of need
cons:
Made to feel like you don't matter 
Pushed and pressured for spikes all the time 
Clear favoritism shown towards particular volunteers
Management does not address concerns of volunteers. 
Pressured to take more conversations at a time than comfortable with. Would texters be happy to know they might be one of 6 people you are talking to at once? 
Insensitivity to cultural issues. Assumes we are all the same.

review_title: There are very concerning practices here
pros: Training is free for volunteers and the scheduling is very flexible.
cons: I attended this organizations annual conference this past weekend. I was glad to see they have hired a Chief Medical Officer as their main supervisor does not have a masters degree and frankly is unprofessional and immature. She is constantly talking about unicorn farts rather than providing support to volunteers. After this weekend, I am very concerned about how many current volunteers were triggered and actively suicidal. I am shocked that Crisis text line does not do more screening to ensure their volunteers are stable. This is important work and a suicidal person should not be providing support to someone in Crisis. It's unbelievable that these people have not been asked to take a break, very dangerous for themselves and texters.

pros: I think that Crisis Text Line is going to change the world of mental health and it is amazing that they're offering their services to texters for free! I can't wait to see how the company grows and what strides they will make in the realm of mental health and data collection.
cons: It appears that the most valued employees are those who are on the tech team, a product of nepotism, or are white. The opportunity for growth among minorities at Crisis Text Line is laughable. They claim to value diversity, but only if there is a financial incentive behind it - even then, they drag their feet! They're a company who has an external focus on mental health but internally focuses too much on making money while and getting people to do the HARD work for free because its for a good "cause". The CEO makes it clear that the tech team is more valuable and will get paid more than the employees who actually care about mental health and are training and producing thousands of crisis counselors to - the backbone of the organization! If you are young, single, have no family, no social life, like to work 24/7 just to be noticed, don't expect to put you college or graduate degree to real use, are a tech or data person, and don't have strong cultural values...then this is the place for you!

pros: The opportunity to help people experiencing mental health crises or just having a hard time is wonderful. There are also many perks provided by CTL for the Crisis Counselors
cons: The training seems incomplete and does not prepare you for handling specific issues. They teach you a formula for “active listening” and reflecting things back. This is not always effective and can feel very cold to texters if not done in a certain way. There is very little feedback during training or after shifts. There is pressure to wrap up conversations in a very short amount of time. There have also been leadership issues and racism that caused the CEO to be ousted. I was not privy to these issues though, so I can only speak to the experience as a volunteer.

review_title: Be aware of the happy go lucky facade.
pros: Some days I feel like I might have actually helped someone in crisis. There’s also decent compensation in effort to balance out how unhappy you’ll be working here.
cons:
I haven’t disliked a job in a long time but I can officially say this one makes the list. I’m used to being in high pressure and fast paced work environments but CTL is that on top of the nonsense that goes on internally. The amount of turnover in the last 8 months is ridiculous and most of that has been on the Supervision team. Supervision is constantly overlooked for the work they do on a daily bases. Working from home could be a pro if supervisors weren’t forced to accept awful schedules, feeling tethered to your computer and feeling stretched thin at all times. Work life balance...where? Because it’s not here. You’ll work holidays, weekends, nights, be expected to have all of the answers while on the platform and multitask the hell out of things so be prepared. Btw at one point supervisors were told they shouldn’t be multitasking. An example of how petty things can be at CTL sometimes. Supervisors seem to be less and less satisfied as far as their value at CTL is concerned. Even though they’re on the front lines with crisis counselors the crisis counselors are clearly the holy grail. Going to a company conference, having a 10-12hr day of smiling/socializing/making small talk then having to do my actual job duties shows how much supervisors are valued. 

What do supervisors get? Often it’s just the short end of the stick...Oh and being reminded “You can work from anywhere”  but it’s shift work. Who wants to do that from anywhere? If in-office staff gets summer Fridays and that week off between Christmas and New Year. Once again what to supervisors get? Other than discouraged to take time off or sick days unless absolutely necessary because of the recent spike in turnover. 

Tons of policy/procedure changes that make it hard to keep up with how things are done. Change can become a fearful thing with all of the emails saying were doing this one way this week and then next week were actually going to do it another way for the next 5 days. Then you’re in a meeting and there’s yet another change to that same procedure but only until 2am this time next Tuesday. Very confusing. 

CTL wants more diversity and inclusion but it’s moving along very slowly. For a while it seemed like the only thing moving forward was advancing more women to management positions, which is great! However when the majority of those are women are non people of color I feel like the inclusion stopped there. Btw, no HR so there’s no one to go to in confidence when you feel uncomfortable with what’s being said or done. There’s a culture at CTL that seems extremely fake especially with all of the office gossip and noticeable dissension. This culture feels forced upon employees and is actually very uncomfortable when there are boundaries you’re used to having between your coworkers and your after work life.  CTL is not a mental health agency it’s a tech company (you’ll be reminded of that). So keep that fresh in your mind if you come from a social work, human service, psych, etc background. It’ll be interesting until it’s not and then you’ll understand why it isn’t a mental health agency.

review_title: Not really caring about mental health
pros: Good at risk assessment of texters. Good data insights about their texters.
cons:
Not sure where to even start.  The crisis counselors are pushed to get volumes of texters through as opposed to providing them with actual care. It's about quantity of those served, not quality. 

Texters can see right through the techniques that the crisis counselors have been taught. It's lip service. If you're really not a high risk, suicidal person then CTL is not the place you should be texting into.  They don't want you spending a lot of time on calls with the texter. They want you to rapidly move through their protocols and get the next texter on the line. 

They pass themselves off as more than just a crisis line in that you can call in if you're being bullied, depressed, have anxiety...etc but their staff is not allowed to work with you towards anything other than quick coping redirects. It's reiterated time and time again that we are not therapists.  But a lot of the texters need just that--someone to talk to, to listen, and give them guidance. CTL wants the texter to do all the work so they feel empowered, but more often than not the texters calling in can't figure out a good solution THAT'S WHY THEY'RE TEXTING IN! And the crisis counselors have to sit there and keep asking them (in various ways) what they think the best solution is to empower them. 

As a person who's called a suicide hotline in my youth and as an employee of CTL, I can tell you that really, they're no more than a suicide hotline via text. They don't know how to really handle any other sort of issue a texter might have that isn't a high risk texter.

review_title: Good opportunity - easy with flexible hours
pros:
1. Flexible hours
2. The training is short (30 hours) and prepares you well for using their model and philosophy.
3. Volunteers are, in my experience, universally kind. There is a debrief chatroom where you can vent about whatever you want and they will give you compliments.
4. Most conversations are on mundane topics so its not very stressful. The most common crises are (roughly in order): breakups, feeling lonely, feeling sad, panic attacks, urge to self-harm, anxiety about schoolwork, and anxiety about finances. You will probably talk to about one person a month with a plan for suicide.
5. Some of the supervisors are nice.
6. [Mixed] I've only interacted with Nancy a handful of times. She is definitely abrasive but she also sends volunteers messages saying she appreciates their effort so, go figure. You probably won't interact with her much.
cons:
1. Some of the supervisors are not nice and most are slow to respond if you need support.
2. I got the sense CTL's data science team is out of its depth basically. They talk a lot about conclusions from their research but I got the sense it is not particularly good research. From what I could tell it is all observational  but they draw causal conclusion. This is a no-no in most sciences, even soft sciences like psychology and economics.
3. Some conversations are on heavy topics like detailed plans for suicide, physical violence, and sexual assault. A small fraction of texters are also abusive but this is far lower than the number on a phone suicide hotline.
4. Many people who text in are probably harmed a little by the service so you'll be a small part of that. CTL does not to encourage people to use the service as a way to avoid dealing with their problems but the nature of being there 24/7, always listening, naturally does lead to that. I don't think you're going to cripple anyone's recovery but you probably won't feel good about it.

review_title: Good Vision and the Heart is in the Right Place - BAD OFFICE CULTURE
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The position is great if you can ignore all the slack banter and complaining. The pay is decent. You feel like you are making a difference. Supervisors and Coaches get to work from home. The schedule is flexible.
cons:
When I was hired a few years ago I was told that you had have a Master's degree. Funny though, not all supervisors and coaches have a masters and some don't even have a bachelors degree!  How qualified can you be when this is your first real job?  

There are way too many useless meetings.  These meetings consist of non-stop complaining or pretentious one-upping another trying to sound all smart in front of the CEO.  When will people learn that you don't have to talk for the sake of hearing yourself talk, especially when the topic has been repeated over and over again. 

There is no HR so if you have an HR issue there is nobody to go to. The CEO thinks hiring an HR is a bad idea.  

Nancy, the CEO, will often log on to the platform to take shifts and then put the supervisors on the spot by asking them how she can improve. Is that a trick question?  She doesn't really want to know she can improve. She loves putting people in uncomfortable situations (and has admitted that.) She does it often with the office employees, at staff retreats, etc.  

The company is going through massive change right now which is good - hopefully the CEO can be a little more hands off and let the leadership teams do their job.  Change is good - it's how a company grows but what is annoying AF is how everyone is constantly complaining when things change. Why?  If the employees would just remember as the CEO stated: this is a tech company first and saving lives just happens to be part of it then all would be good. But most employees spend way too much time trying to change this or change that as opposed to staying focused on what's important.  Supervisors and coaches were hired to do one job and that's supervise and coach. You're either in it or you're not. What surprises me is how there is no structure or management when it comes to complaining.  

But here's where it gets good.  Every year there is a company retreat and other silly meetups throughout.  Unless you are super young, want to stay up all night partying, and then engage in ridiculous embarrassing team building experiences (think: scavenger hunts that require you to prank call someone or tweet something from your personal account) then this experience will be absolutely horrific. They make you SHARE A ROOM with other employees.  Yes that's right - you have no privacy for 4 days because you have to SHARE A FREAKING ROOM.  Just as I thought we were past that stage - (CEO just got done raising millions more and then goes on to brag about it) they announce another retreat that's even worse than the last few.  Not to mention, there are many employees who are being required to leave their little ones for a week.  That's right - even if you made your own accommodations you do not have a choice on where you stay.  One employee asked if she could bring her newborn and husband so she could breast feed in the room while she participated in the day activities and the answer was no.  I have worked at jobs where travel was required and never in my life have I had to share a room with a random stranger. I say random because this is a work at home job and you don't know your co-workers in person. They don't let you choose your roommate so you are stuck with whomever.  Good luck if your roommate snores or is up all night on their phone. Yes - that has happened to me. 

They talk about self-care but it's nothing that is actually implemented and there are no real employee perks accept a few free apps here and there.  The job is hard and really takes a toll so it would be nice to have some real perks like other large companies (not everyone lives by a soul cycle.)

There is a lot of office drama when someone gets promoted and people talking behind other people's backs, yet when they are looking at each other face to face or when they are online, it is ridiculously fake and upbeat.

review_title: If you are committed to mental health, think twice!
pros: Relaxed work environment, can be very attractive initiatlly
cons: By far, this was the most traumatizing and ridiculous work experience of my life. I have never encountered a more unprofessional staff in terms of favortism, use of inappropriate language (with the facade of being "hip") and especially racial and cultural insensitivity. The organization claims to care about the work and be committed to its mission, but the office culture promoted anything but. The organization as a whole is much more committed to being a fashionable start-up than one committed to promoting mental health. If you are a committed mental health professional, I suggest going elsewhere as this organization is more about "talking the talk" than "walking the walk"

pros: The mission is great, and that's what drives the staff here. The people that work here are some of the most amazing and talented people I have ever met. They have good benefits and days off, and that's probably what keeps the staff. The people here really do their best regardless of the nonsense that comes from the CEO.
cons:
Don't be fooled by the volunteers pretending to be employees. THEY ARE NOT EMPLOYEES! They do not know what happens outside of their volunteering.

The CEO is a tyrant that promotes toxic work culture. The people that get along with her are brainwashed like a cult! She uses the organization to boost her ego by making everyone else feel small. If you're a yes person then maybe this is the right place for you because they'll call it a "positive, can do attitude." If you're looking at being a Supervisor or Coach be prepared to be given the lowest salary they can offer. Every other role is given a respectable salary except those people, which is outrageous. Your degree and experience don't matter in those roles. They claim to promote diversity and inclusion, but they do not! The most diverse this place gets is Caucasian, Gay, or Jewish. I feel for anyone that works here and is not one of those demographics. The CEO openly admits to actively hiring people of color when it needs to benefit the org, which is when they're getting money or need to look good for press. They recently started employee resource groups, which sounds positive but is likely a scam to keep the staff distracted so they don't focus on the executives' terrible practices. If you think this is the place to grow your career - think again! Promotions are only given to a select few and their friends. The CEO flip flops all the time. Staff are scared of Nancy's reactions. She believes in public shaming. At some point in their time here, almost everyone has left a meeting crying because of the ridiculous comments and expectations.

pros: The intent is there and the genuine of volunteers to want to make a difference and supervisors to be supportive and driven by what they do versus what they put up with. They give "perks" when you reach certain levels which--in my view, is a way to help reduce "churn" (because there is a high turnover rate among crisis counselors). They have partnerships with organizations that may not see through the facade that allow for crisis counselors to get reduced costs for a limited time or free merchandise Etc. So the incentives exists. They are pro-data which is awesome and they love sharing it all the time.
cons:
First, as a crisis counselor, I'm asked to take on multiple conversations on a regular basis not directly (though I have been at times) but indirectly through staff note pop ups while I'm crisis counseling, messages in the global chat and the push in the newsletter sent out to current volunteers. It's a bit redundant and pushy in my view and not everyone can handle the conversation limits. I can but I know myself and for some people it's just not for them to take more than two conversations and they shouldn't be pressured to on a constant basis. There is the push for quality but really that is hidden under the bigger push for quantity.
We're expected to wrap up conversations with "low-risk" texter's in 45 minutes or less even if they need more time to talk, it's not encouraged. I kind of do what I want with this though since I've been around for a while and I care more about quality of conversations rather than quantity. I'd rather give them as much time as I can/they need so they can go on to more long-term resources over minimizing their time and ability to be more open because I have a time-constraint that is not self-imposed. I'm volunteering by the way so I choose the freedom with my time on the platform whether or not it is noticed.
Hiring. In looking at a current job posting on the corporate website for a Crisis Counselor Supervisor, the requirements are clear: a master's degree in a related field and if one is not present, a master's degree in a different field with a bachelor's in a human-services field plus relevant experience. This is not necessarily true and does not reflect the quality of supervision given on the platform for volunteers. We have (that I am aware of) at least two supervisors who do not have master's degrees in a related field or bachelor's. There is no indication they have adequate experience that is equal either. The should not be allowed to continue supervision unless they are enhancing their education and receiving those degrees to be equivalent to new hires or have acquired more advanced knowledge. 
For one of the supervisors in particular her lack of awareness, ethics and other mannerisms important to this line of work is very evident in how she treats the counselors while they are volunteering.
Lastly, there have to be improvements made or this company will fall based upon poor management and direction or someone is going to sue some day for the amount of flaws present here. Which, would be quite unfortunate since the concept does work and the demand for such a service exists but leaning towers can only stand for so long.

pros: Hard to say, honestly. Maybe they offer above-market salaries compared to other nonprofits?
cons:
CEO and COO are horrible managers and incompetent. You won't learn nearly as fast here as other places, mostly because your projects will be taken from you randomly, your goals will be reset, and 70% of the staff is looking to quit. 

Previous glassdoor review mentioned that the CEO runs her nonprofit like Donald Trump. Spot-on. 

Look up the Racked article about Miki Agrawal, the former CEO of Thinx. She's extremely similar to the current CEO of CTL, to the extent that this Racked article was passed around CTL. 

Don't work here.

pros:
brief, very focused, and effective training
supportive atmosphere, cares about your well-being as a counselor
data driven counseling
fulfills a niche need in the mental health community
cons: Can't think of any, the volunteer hours are short, its an amazing experience to make a real difference

pros: It's amazing to go to work every day and know that you are working on projects that are quite literally saving people's lives. I love the vision of the org and the coworkers are some of the kindest, hardest working folks I've worked with. Opportunities to work on projects that you're passionate about are everywhere. And, there are a ton of opportunities to learn and try new things.
cons: I don't consider this a con because I think it is simply part of growth. But, Crisis Text Line is still in start-up mode.

review_title: Wonderful mission, but can it grow well?
pros:
Incredible, worthwhile mission: we are literally saving lives from our laptops. CTL provides an unbelievably important service (with no shortage of people in pain, it’s much-needed) and it’s humbling to make a difference in the world by showing empathy to strangers. Being a volunteer Crisis Counselor is an amazing way to gain experience in mental health and I appreciate that I can give my time on a flexible, remote basis.

The volunteer training is also top-notch: it’s clear, comprehensive and walks you through what to expect from conversations. I felt very well-prepared for my role and the educational resources available are plentiful. Overall, the staff and volunteers I’ve met are an inspiring, compassionate group: united in our desire to support and empower those in crisis, CTL’s community is something special.
cons:
As others have mentioned, it can sometimes feel like quantity (number of convos taken, number of people texting in) is valued over quality,
meaning that the company’s striving to grow bigger without necessarily having support structures in place to do so.  A recent example is the #GivingTime initiative that aims to recruit 2,020 new Crisis Counselors by the end of this year. Sounds amazing in theory, but that’s a 40% increase in volunteers and it already feels like coaches/supervisors have too many people to monitor. There are certainly plenty of texters on the Platform, but my perception is that current CCs could benefit from more coaching/feedback to grow their skills vs. simply bringing more and more people onboard.

pros: Being able to help others. There are some perks depending on your level.
cons: When I first started volunteering the motto was"if it's a crisis to you,  it's a crisis to us". Somewhere along the line, it changed to "only if the texter is immediate danger should we worry". Those texters that need to vent and talk are "low risk" and we need to be delt with quickly. It's almost like hearding cattle.

pros: rewarding, developing communication skills, helps in everyday life
cons: can be stressful with high queues and active rescues, constant pressure to do more

pros: I have been there about 3 months and have been able to help many people through different situations.
cons: I am a retired nurse not allowed to use any of that training, I have a business degree keep  to myself, I am currently a minister really stop.34 hours of training is no way enough hours to do the job the right way that they expect. right now I have been suspended until I talk to my coach on Tuesday about not properly using the policies of the company. But yet after becoming a level 2 counselor you are allowed to take on more than one texters, than you have supervisors jumping in telling you are doing a great job you got this keep going, while going behind your back saying you are not following policy really. And than you are limited to 20 hours a week and you have supervisors texting that they are overwhelmed can you help than you get texted because your over 20 hours. Does this sound like you are helping .you can not use personal life, you can not give or even hint towards advise. Many of my callers just fade away because they want help not me asking them very strange things. Well I will see after Tuesday

pros:
✅REMOTE WORK✅ 
This is the BEST pro. If it weren’t for the ability to work remotely, I would have to continue working locally with an hour commute for some cruddy, boring, lower functioning org (not a ton of work opportunities locally). The remote work definitely has its own set of challenges, but it gives me the opportunity to feel excited and passionate about the work that  I am doing. It can be tough in this hectic life to fulfill your goals as mom, wife, daughter, sister, etc. AND as strong career, goal oriented woman too. The opportunity to work remotely on the CTL platform allows me the chance to be close to my family, all while working in what I would define as the DREAM job. A job that far exceeds and surpasses what other opportunities exist in my rural Midwest community. 

✅Work Smarter, Not Harder✅
From everything I have come to learn about Crisis Text Line, I am consistently impressed with what the organization is doing and how they are doing it. The level of communication that’s achieved via texting nowadays is incredible. Crisis Intervention delivered via texting is beyond genius in so many ways. The procedural designs and systems set in place further embrace the power in providing interventions using this medium. CTL has enormous strength in what they are doing, brilliance in how they do it and limitless possibilities looking into the future. 

✅Powerhouse Team✅
I have worked a couple different full-time (in person) professional positions during the past five years. In just a short time, I can honestly say that CTL is the most supportive and collaborative working team I have ever been a part of. Questions are heard and responded to promptly. Co-workers volunteer and volunteer often to help one another out. For most upcoming and prosperous organizations, it can be challenging to focus on staff as there are a bajillion other things that require the leadership’s time. CTL still somehow always manages to put their employees first, regardless of new transitions. They genuinely care not only about staffs well being, but the crisis counselors and the texters well being too. Supervision team does not have an easy role whatsoever, but they sure are fully backed and supported by the teams entirety.

✅Incentives✅
Insurance package is covered 100% by the employer. That alone is extremely rare. Pay is competitive. Ability to work nonconforming hours with flexible scheduling. If you enjoy traveling, there are frequent opportunities for travel. Inspiring and encouraging leadership to work under.
cons: Scheduling can be difficult for supervision team as we are staffed 24/7/365. Make sure you know how to keep yourself awake at night. You have to be tuned in and present the entire shift. It is HARD work, but rewarding would not even begin to describe the way you feel after a shift. If travel isn’t for you and you don’t live locally, the amount of time you have to travel may be considered a con. The pros far outweigh the cons in my opinion.

review_title: A Culture of Toxicity and Fear
pros: You will feel like you are doing something good in the beginning of your time at CTL.
cons:
All of the following is, in some way, related to Nancy Lublin, the CEO and Founder. Because she gives no true ownership to her employees, and runs her organization according to a culture of fear and emotional abuse, every "con" listed is going to relate to her. If you are lucky enough to be mostly shielded from Nancy by your direct manager (a common practice by the good middle managers that remain at this company), you are still at risk for traumatic emotional abuse, and are still contributing to the ethically questionable practices that occur here on the daily.

CTL is morally and ethically corrupt: 
- Volunteer crisis counselors are incentivized with gift cards and other rewards to take more conversations than they are equipped for. This is an extremely concerning practice for the people in crisis. It is also concerning for the crisis counselors who will deal (and do deal) with the trauma of being pushed to take more conversations, and therefore, are unable to counsel these people safely. 
- Nancy encourages misleading data. For example, she instructs staff and counselors to log into the crisis counseling platform simply to increase the number of "active crisis counselors." 
- Nancy takes conversations with people in crisis--an ethically questionable practice considering her skill as a counselor. She often tells these individuals in crisis to "just go to sleep" or "listen to Taylor Swift." Though Nancy claims her counseling skills are good, and above the average, they are not. Her data team tells her that is higher than most people on staff, and it is not. It is below the organization's average. 
- Her for-profit company (Loris) has more access to CTL's data than Nancy is letting on. She claims that no identifiable information is shared across companies--but her for-profit data team has access to CTL's data team.

Nancy leads a culture of toxicity and fear: 
- Nancy runs her organization like the president of the U.S. runs  his administration. Like Trump, Nancy throws tantrums when she doesn't get her way. Like Trump, when she is challenged, she responds with yelling, or name-calling, or a campaign of gossiping and badmouthing that person.
- Nancy often publicly shaming employees in staff meetings-banging on furniture, or screaming and interrupting. People are afraid to speak up. 
- Nancy is insensitive and bigoted, and makes racist comments frequently. Nancy (at work, in front of her staff), has said things like, "our supervision team has too many fat people," and refers to staff by their ethnicity, race, gender or sexual orientation. 
- Most staff members that work regularly with Nancy have required therapy to cope with the emotionally abusive cycle they are a part of. 

I urge you to be careful about working here: for your physiological and emotional health, for your mental sanity, for your values and ethics. Pay attention to the reviews that seem thorough, and real ("Ethical does not exist here," from April 2018; "Dictatorship" from May 2017; "What Happened If Donald Trump [sic] A Nonprofit" from August 2016, to name only a few) versus the short and incomplete-seeming reviews that are mostly written by crisis counselors (who are part time volunteers, and who are almost never at their office). CTL may eventually respond to this review with something trite and glib. Please trust your gut, and stay away.

pros: Macbooks at work. (also, glassdoor told me i needed at least 5 words in this section. Biggest struggle. )
cons:
I'll keep it short and sweet because every negative review here is 100% accurate. Every positive review here is either written by a misguided volunteer (non employee) or an exec team member pretending to be someone else to get the ratings up. Pathetic. 

The CEO is a terror. She's nice in public, nice in media interviews and a complete terror with her employees. All the accusations about her prejudice and racist behavior is 100% accurate. She refuses to acknowledge that she is the problem and there is absolutely no way a person of color in the org will give her real feedback on her behavior because they fear getting fired. Nancy, just because people don't tell you that you're a racist to your face, does not mean you aren't one. You are. 

Crisis Counselors: You are lovely volunteers but know that Nancy came up with ways to categorize you all when you do things that she deems is "bad." She calls you a funky apple and you are categorized by these labels. 

Vampires. CC’s who are on the platform more than 12 hours a week

Creepers. Inappropriate conversation with a Texter, Trainer, CC, or Staff member

Snowdens. Person posting confidential info on social media and/or breaking confidentiality of the texters

Jessica Joneses. Crisis Counselor that is Triggered while taking a convo or something traumatic happens in their personal life.

The Chronics. A Crisis Counselor or Trainee who continually uses our texting service for their own long term issue.

Know-it-alls. Crisis Counselors who offer medical or general advice to texters and report MR/AR without support from the supervisor

CCs, stop idolizing Nancy, stop thinking she's god.  She's not and every time you compliment her, you make her worse. You are part of the problem. She actually does not care for you.

Crisis Text Line Board: You should be ashamed of yourselves. The organization's employees are suffering and you continue to be fooled by Nancy. She needs to be removed from this org and needs to be sent far away from everyone here. 

Refinery 29. You were going to write an expose on Nancy. She's worse than Miki Agarwal. Continue with your article. It will be a service to humanity if you expose her. 

Prospective New Hires: If you read these glassdoor reviews and still choose to work here, you're like Nancy. You keep Hillary Clinton on your lips but have Alt-right in your heart. Any prospective hire that doesn't read glassdoor reviews, they'll begin to hate the place before their 3 months are up.

pros: Rewarding, excellent training, team atmosphere, everyone works together and cares for each other and the texters.  The full time employees are excellent, compassionate, and go out of their way to treat volunteers with care and respect.  Cannot say enough great things about CTL.  JOIN
cons: I really cannot think of one, it's open 24/7 so you pick own hours, and when you can't work, no problem.

pros:
- Crisis Text Line generally hires motivated individuals that are extremely talented throughout the org (with the exception of the new hiring practices for supervisors)

- Most can work remotely

- Champagne when you kiss the CEO's bum

- A lot of paid holidays
cons:
- Inconsistent rules/regulations/policies: Exec team meets and decides how to govern the organization. The emails get sent out once per week with general policy changes and implementation. These change weekly as well as daily depending on which exec team member you talk to. 

- COO: very manipulative. Causes fires between employees for her own entertainment as well as to push her own agenda.

CEO: Very moody and unpredictable. Has no idea what she wants and will literally scream at her employees in front of everyone in order to get her way/break people down.

- No HR: Org refuses to have an HR department. CEO and others will be extremely inappropriate with employees. For example: asking a male employee that is out of state to keep talking during a meeting so she can drool over his attractive face and voice.

- Supervisors: Originally had to have MSW or similar for the ethics of the position (mandated reporting, calling in for DTO/DTS). Most qualified supervisors have left due to new hiring practices stating anyone can be a supervisor. This puts our texters at risk.

- Data: Most of the data is not accurate or so skewed from the truth. None of what is published can be replicated. Most of the issue tagging is done by volunteers and is not accurate to the population the org serves. Diagnosing a texter when they are experiencing a crisis by an untrained professional is unacceptable. 

- CEO consistently asks for volunteers and her favorite employees to write positive reviews on this site to offset the truthful reviews. Seems pretty unethical.

pros:
- A truly worthy cause: helping people in dire need in an innovative way
- The volunteers who spend their free time supporting strangers in crisis - it's a beautiful thing
- Casual dress code 
- Macbooks for staff 
- No out of pocket for medical (but those benefits are just so-so)
cons:
What a shame so much of CTL's mission is left unfulfilled due to the misplaced and wasted effort spent protecting the CEO's psyche.  It's choose your own adventure at CTL, with just two choices: agree with everything the she says - or leave. The office is a minefield: proceed with extreme caution around the CEO. If she likes you (because you say yes to everything that comes out of her mouth), you're her pet and she'll shower you with praise and champagne and trips to Jamaica. If she doesn't like you (e.g. you offer differing opinions or ideas) she'll make your life miserable. 

It's about assimilation, not performance, at CTL - which is why more than half of the turnover over the last year impacted people of color. The exec team is young and inexperienced and have never worked for anyone but the CEO - this is by design. The CEO finds yes-people whom she can control and receive constant self-validation. In fact, it seems as though the only purpose of the Executive Team to provide a shield to protect the CEO's fragile ego. 

As an employee you'll be subject to these people who are her puppets and will immediately throw you under the bus in tough situations. It may seem like a fulfilling and groundbreaking place to work at first, with lots of perks, but this superficial bait will wear off very quickly and you'll be very unlikely to make it to that 2nd year to go on any sabbatical.

pros: Great mission. You can literally save lives. Generally good people below the C/Management level (CTO's on point though)
cons: CTL isn't an organization where work is distributed or people are trusted to do their jobs.  Nancy (the CEO) has a little egomaniacal dictatorship going complete with a weekly royal court where everyone in the company is required to attend and watch as Nancy makes decisions.  No detail is to small, and if she changes her mind after 6 months of work, well... that's a you problem.

review_title: What happened if Donald Trump ran a nonprofit?
pros:
This is a great place to work if you :

- love free food

-  love a fast moving organization- so fast paced, you will most likely end up taking on projects with virtually no timelines just because the CEO says so

- love sheer confusion. You’re told that you can’t be friends with your co-workers, cannot be a family but then also are told to have fun in the office and bond with your coworkers

- are White. Racial minorities can run away. RUN. Just RUN. and don’t look back. The CEO will try to hire you, but not on merit, just based on the color of your skin and then tokenize you in front of board members and funders claiming she’s hired a diverse staff. If you do choose to put yourself through this job, be prepared to be on the receiving end of constant micro-agressions and then in turn be forced to have conversations with the CEO listening to her talk about how much she is aware of her privilege. If you’ve been watching Fox News your whole life you may, just may be able to handle working under the exec team.
cons:
- Quantity over Quality.The organization loves its numbers. It’s all about the number of conversations our Crisis Counselors take and any quality measurement is irrelevant. The most recent example, is awarding all volunteers that have taken 100 conversations with $500, with no attention to their quality ratings. In fact, if we did care about quality, we wouldn’t have untrained staff take conversations on the platform putting our texters at risk. 

- Zero Integrity. The entire executive team will throw any employee under the bus in a split second, no questions asked. It seems like the exec team often gets amnesia, they tell you to do one thing and then when things hits the fan, they forget they gave you that directive in the first place. There’s no point getting anything in writing either, you’ll be labeled as a complainer and an unkind person. 

- Zero Job Security. The CEO will pay her employees to leave the organization. This offer, disguised as an “out for unhappy employees” really is a ploy to cleanse the organization of people Nancy does not like. Employees are coerced into taking this “amazing offer” when really she’s essentially firing employees but getting out of a giving them a decent severance package

pros:
Great mission which is unfortunately ultimately a vessel for CEO's personal brand. You'll bond with other non exec team staff like you're all in a foxhole together.

If you MUST work here, you're best off working remotely where you can tune out of the toxic culture most of the time.
cons:
Passionate people come to work here only to find out that the image of the company they interviewed at was a farce. The CEO runs EVERYTHING here. You might have a manager, but ultimately you will get micromanaged by the CEO, whether that is directly or indirectly through your manager. 

If you like getting Slack messages from your CEO after midnight about changes that needed to be made because any planning that is done here is thrown out the window at every stage of the process, you'll love it here. Make no mistake, if you're a tech person, there is no process for product here. If you're not a tech person, be prepared to get roped into doing "product" that constantly changes depending on the CEO's mood that day.

Other comments: zero culture. ZERO. Be prepared to be criticized behind closed doors by the exec team if you forge personal friendships here.

The only thing I learned here was how toxic a workplace can get just from having a bad leader. There are enough good people working here that this could actually be a great place, if it wasn't for the CEO.

I haven't worked here for months and I still am traumatized by my experience here.

Avoid avoid avoid.

review_title: Takes special people to work here
pros:
The people here are all compassionate about helping others, including the tech team! 
The benefits are top notch. Knowing your are providing change in peoples lives daily is more than you can every ask for.
cons: Change happens all the time, this can be challenging to some.

pros: Lots of capable, intelligent, and passionate young people work here.
cons:
Working at Crisis Text Line continues to be one of the worst decisions I've ever made. The tension in the office everyday makes me feel like I'm going to vomit. What the company preaches is far from what it practices, though Nancy (the CEO) has lately had a more difficult time keeping the toxic side of herself from her volunteers.  The organizational culture is emotionally abusive, stemming from the CEO but also from the soon-to-be former COO. More concerning than anything though, is that this behavior is at a nonprofit organization that provides mental health services nationwide. Also concerning is the complete lack of regard for evidence-based and ethical practices. 

Notable examples: 

Suicidal volunteer crisis counselors who have texted into the service themselves requiring emergency services are allowed to continue providing crisis counseling services without concern for their own well-being and the well-being of our texters. Exec doesn’t want to upset the volunteer community or put people off by making someone wait after an inpatient hospitalization. 

Despite the company’s marketing that CTL serves people going through any type of crisis, the CEO decided that "relationship texters" (people in crisis due to a romantic relationship) are not truly in crisis. Volunteers must quickly end the conversation after a few minutes, getting to other texters so better wait times can be achieved for funders. COO Baylee addressed concerns of this change by saying, “This is a business, not a democracy.” 

Supervisors of volunteer counselors are no longer required to have master's degrees or relevant experience because the exec team got tired of the team identifying ethical issues and felt concern about licensed staff being required to report what they have seen in the organization. Mental health professionals expressing concern are told that if they don’t want to be here they should leave. They’re listening: 5 have left since August, and more will leave soon.

I could continue writing on and on about the daily concerns of the entire staff. Crisis Text Line is not run by anyone with mental health education and experience, and the staff that do have these qualifications are silenced when they advocate against concerning practices. Staff are told that if they have a "negative attitude" they will be let go, and they have followed through on this threat before. The services that are provided by the organization are poor, and at this point they will lead to the death of our texters by suicide if they haven't already. Our entire staff is aware of how toxic the company is, but we’re all living in fear.

review_title: fun, fast moving company to work at
pros:
*super high impact work (sadly pain and suffering is a growth business)
*learn a ton (CTL is growing like a weed)
*can't think of a more effective social impact technology company
*save lives every day
cons:
*it's intense (there is a lot of pain and suffering out there)
*sometimes it feels like we're drinking from a fire hose

review_title: Inspiring... a job that will propel you to the next level
pros:
-Intelligent, passionate staff. Everyone is very supportive of each other. 
-Opportunity for growth. Leadership encourages staff to try new things and develop new roles. Promotions are based on smart work- every one has the opportunity to grow within the org. 
-Meaningful work, innovative approach.
cons:
-This isn't a 9-5 job, staff is on most of the time.
-Fast paced environment- its not for everyone!
-Topic is heavy by nature. Not recommended for those easily triggered.

pros: It's challenging to think of pros other than the salary is on the higher end. Many people who are and have been employed here truly want to do good in the world (which is why many of them end up leaving).
cons:
This organization is a business designed to make volunteers and employees feel good about themselves for "saving lives". This is not and has never been an organization that cares about mental health (or texters, volunteers, or employees.) Let's break it down.

Volunteers. The CEO is very focused on numbers no matter the cost. Many volunteers are accepted despite their own mental health challenges, including recent suicide attempts. This is extremely dangerous not only for the volunteer, but also for the texters who reach out needing crisis support. It is unacceptable to allow someone who is in crisis to provide crisis support to another person. But, because that increases how many active volunteers there are and how many conversations CTL has provided, it's "okay" per the CEO. The screening process for volunteers is horrible, and once they are brought on they are poorly trained. CTL does not care about the quality of interventions just that they keep spitting out "crisis counselors" like a factory. If a CC has bad quality, nothing is done to try to help them. CTL wants to make the CCs feel good about themselves, they don't care how it impacts texters in crisis. Speaking of CCs, the majority of the positive reviews on here are written by volunteers who spend 4 hours a week with CTL and have no idea what management is like when they take the mask off. 

Employees. CTL hires driven, and talented people to work for them. But, it's a waste as the CEO does not allow them to contribute or actually make any decisions. The CEO is a dictator and will have you redo something because she is the only one who knows what's best. Leadership rotates every 6 months so that the only person who has power is the CEO. The CEO has made references that degrees of employees do not matter - MSW, Counseling, PhD - you name it. None of these degrees matter or influence how a person works in the mental health space. "Any one can do those jobs". CTL has started hiring unqualified staff so that they can't speak up about unethical practices as a licensed professional would. Not only do they not have the skills to provide the necessary support, but they become the CEO's pawn since they will not make a similar salary elsewhere and are stuck in the org. CTL does not care about best practices or utilizing current mental health knowledge and research. They rely on their own "data", but forget the basic principle from Research 101 that correlation does not equal causation. Then again, anything one learned in school does not matter as the CEO knows best. The CEO pretends to care about diversity when in actuality she is very racist. While searching for a CMO candidate she said in an all staff meeting "I will only hire a black person for this job because we need diversity in leadership." Anyone who speaks up about unethical practices is promptly fired for being "too negative".

Texters. People who reach out to CTL in crisis receive poor support. If their crisis is not "bad enough" they are turned away or the CC quickly closes the conversation. Never mind the fact that many people will reach out with something trivial to test the waters before disclosing that they are actually suicidal. CTL does not care about this because they just want to open and close as many conversations as possible.  As I stated above volunteers are under trained and not equipped to assess and provide appropriate support. This can be extremely detrimental to someone who is reaching out in a time of crisis.

pros: You're positively impacting the lives of real people and helping them feel less alone :) The techniques you learn in training may be useful to you in your own life too.
cons: This isn't a huge con for me personally but a lot of CC's have said that they spend a lot of time waiting in the queue to get texters. There's definitely peak times where that hasn't been the case for me. Regardless, I don't mind the wait because it means that all our texters get quicker responses from us!

pros:
Opportunity to support people in crisis (if given the space to do so)
Great volunteers and some excellent staff members
cons:
I've become increasingly concerned by inconsistent practices and messaging by leadership staff about the mission of Crisis Text Line. I have noticed that broad, nonspecific messaging about who we serve (i.e. people who need to talk vs. people in crisis) is bringing on more volume than even 3,000+ crisis counselors can handle, and far more than the small-ish team of supervisors can handle. I have worked with hundreds of texters and have never received feedback, good or bad, on my conversations (despite what is promised in training). I work in mental health and feel pretty confident I'm not doing harm, but I worry about the thousands of other conversations that are not being reviewed and followed up on. I have personally seen some atrocious and disempowering conversations/examples/suggestions shared by other crisis counselors and staff, unfortunately including the CEO Nancy Lublin. At face value it is awesome to see a CEO jump into the trenches to talk with texters when we have high volume, but I would personally hope not to text in and speak with her if I was in crisis based on the snippets she has shared about what she has said or would say to a texter.  I'm concerned about the, for lack of a better term, cult of personality that seems to circulate around certain staff members - it makes their ideas/suggestions unimpeachable even when they don't align with training or best practices.

When volume is very high, crisis counselors are pressured to wrap up conversations quickly and move on to the next texter. We are also pressured to take multiple conversations at a time. Not just 2 or 3, but 4, 5, 6+. In mental health, and especially crisis work, quantity should never be more important than quality.

pros: Volunteering for Crisis Text Line looks great on a resume if you're planning on pursuing a career in mental health services. They offer 30 hours of training, really encourage work-life balance & self-care, and you get to feel like you're making a difference and helping people during every shift. Coaches and supervisors are also really supportive on and off the platform.
cons: Most of the positions are unpaid, volunteer positions. It seems like most of the paid positions that are advertised on the website are in data.

review_title: Fun work environment for good-hearted people
pros:
Complete genuine support for growth personally and at CTL
Open to BIG ideas
Action and solution oriented staff with great management
Culture of kindness
cons: Growing fast!  Sometimes people can take on multiple challenges when theres a lot going on.  Its a chance to get in there and perform at full speed though.

review_title: This is NOT about mental health
pros: I wish I had more to say than free app subscriptions and $10,000 off your tuition of $60,000 but I don’t.
cons:
where does one even begin...

While the PRESENTED idea is great, this is not intended to help anyone with mental health issues or even function as a suicide hotline. It LOOKS great and is probably why so many people fall into the trap of volunteering, but this is all about technology. They will never tell any volunteer this or else there would be no company. For anyone that’s serious about giving back please don’t choose this company. They don’t care about the volunteers or the texters. If you want to help you can volunteer online with NEDA (National Eating Disorder Association) and RAINN (Rape, Abuse, & Incest National Network). Both are wonderful organizations that experts in mental health would agree are far better than a tech company. 

Supervisors pressure many volunteers into taking more conversations than they are mental capable of doing. They have NO empathy and NO credentials. Most supervisors have nothing more than a bachelors and if they have a bachelors I promise you it isn’t in psychology, counseling, developmental science, social work, or anything remotely close to what you would think promotes the best possible supervision team. There was a time supervisors were required to have a masters but those days are long gone. 

If you’re into data analysis you’re in for a treat! They send out a weekly newsletter with their statistics but they only show you positives. You will never see anything negative about what occurs - they must have forgotten the basic rules of good science where both sides are displayed for transparency in methodology. They claim to be open and transparent but I’m not sure about that. Texters don’t know data is being collected about them which is unfortunate as many are minors and cannot consent. Seems like a major legal issue to contend with in the future if this continues.

review_title: Best use of technology for good
pros:
Highly leveraged way to make a difference
Great community of counselors and staff
Save people's lives (in your pajamas)
Training changed the way I communicate and engage with people
cons:
Training is very thorough and time consuming
Some very difficult conversations with texters 
It's scary at first to be on the front line for helping people out (although they have a supervisor keep an eye out for you)

review_title: Current Volunteer, program needs some overhaul
pros: The training is based on the ASIST model, used in various call centers so it is a strong foundation to deescalating clients who are suicidal.  The commitment is capped at 12 hours so you don't feel like you are being stretched too thin. There are some very passionate volunteers you get to work alongside.
cons: As a volunteer,  I have been in at least three incidents where Supervisors have been very aggressive and have made me uncomfortable. I think that Supervisors forget to be "human" with volunteers, and forget to realize that they need more assistance DURING conversations, and not after they have asked a question. Furthermore, volunteers shouldn't feel like they are annoying a Supervisor by reaching out, especially when it comes to immediate risk conversations. More times than not Supervisors are very passive on the platform, only reaching out to say hi, they are going for lunch, and bye. It seems that many comments here echo that. I think that there needs to be more accountability for what is going on with how coaches and supervisors are treating volunteers.  That may solve some of the mysteries about why volunteers aren't being 'retained'.

review_title: BEWARE an organization with no accountability
pros: helps texters at a time of crisis
cons: CTL has run into trouble with social justice issues. They have given lip service by pushing out PR statements put have not allowed for any listening sessions where ccs can speak. Most importantly is uses thousands of volunteers that it keeps at arm's length; you can only communicate via email and there is no due process. What they don't know if CTL records all their convos, not just with texters, but private direct messages between ccs that are stored on their servers to use whenever they want.

pros: Rewarding work, set your own hours, sometimes you can feel you really helped people, some supervisors are extremely helpful
cons: Sometimes ill prepared to help people who are in serious need. Training isn’t extensive enough to cover some of the situations that come up, particularly with regard to mandatory reporting. Also, they’re using all the data for a for profit company (Loris.AI) that’s meant to basically teach customer service people to take abuse better.

pros: The entire application process was easy. You need to do 6 weeks of training which wasn't a lot of work since you spend around 5-6 hours on it each week. After that you just need to work 4 hours per week. Everyone on the platform was warm and friendly.
cons: Some texters were having serious issues in their life but what you can do is so limited so it can be depressing to work there sometimes.

pros:
Good cause saving lives, sort of
Non-exec team bonds in shared misery
cons:
Never know what to expect from the exec team
Boss tells you one thing, then CEO says another
Never know if you're going to have a good or a bad day/week/quarterly review
Go look up "learned helplessness" before working here

pros:
Crisis text line has a great community of counselors, coaches, and supervisors who assist others in need and support each other.

-Good support system
-Compassionate group of people
-A great community 
-Making an impact by helping others who are facing a crisis
